message_1: A spaceship travels at a speed of 0.8c relative to Earth. It releases a probe that travels in the opposite direction at 0.6c relative to the spaceship. What is the velocity of the probe relative to Earth?
message_2:
To find the velocity of the probe relative to Earth, we can use the relativistic velocity addition formula:

v = (v1 + v2) / (1 + (v1 * v2) / c^2)

where v1 is the velocity of the spaceship relative to Earth, v2 is the velocity of the probe relative to the spaceship, and c is the speed of light.

In this case, v1 = 0.8c and v2 = -0.6c (negative because the probe is traveling in the opposite direction relative to the spaceship).

v = (0.8c - 0.6c) / (1 + (0.8c * -0.6c) / c^2)

v = (0.2c) / (1 - 0.48)

v = (0.2c) / 0.52

v â‰ˆ 0.3846c

So, the velocity of the probe relative to Earth is approximately 0.3846c.
